item.title: Accelerator Division’s Rob Reilly retires after 35 years
item.creator: leah
item.description: For 35 years, Rob Reilly of the Accelerator Division Mechanical Support Department has been designing systems that help supply beam to Fermilab’s experiments. Now he is retiring. His last day at Fermilab is Jan. 15.
item.comment:
Rob Reilly’s last day at Fermilab is Jan. 15. Photo: Reidar Hahn

For 35 years, Rob Reilly of the Accelerator Division Mechanical Support Department has been designing systems that help supply beam to Fermilab’s experiments. Now he is retiring. His last day at Fermilab is Jan. 15.

Reilly knows all about focusing and steering beam with magnets, shielding beam and creating a vacuum environment for beam to travel in. He has designed, built and installed adjustable magnet stands, kicker and septum magnets, motorized collimators, beam profile monitors,  and magnetic field and radiation shielding, and titanium vacuum windows, vacuum chambers, pressure tanks and polarity switching tanks. He’s done the same for assembly equipment, such as monorail cranes and heavy-load handling equipment.

After he retires, he will turn his attention from achieving the perfect beam to restoring the perfect antique car, a lifelong hobby. He will also play music on any of his 15 guitars. Most importantly, he’ll spend more time with his grandkids and travel with his wife Jeanine.

There will be a pizza party at the Kuhn Barn on Thursday, Jan 14. Please RSVP to Ruth Becker at x4736 by Jan. 11 if you plan to attend.

item.title: Top seven Employee Advisory Group activities in 2015
item.creator: debseb
item.description: Labwide rollout of flexible work program Anniversary recognition program lunches restart Parental leave policy
item.comment:
1. Labwide rollout of flexible work program
  2. Anniversary recognition program lunches restart
  3. Parental leave policy recommendation (to be rolled out spring 2016)
  4. Mentoring program revitalization recommendation
  5. Food service improvement recommendation (changes to begin later this month)
  6. EAG website enhancements
  7. Free ice cream (after July 2015 all-hands meeting)

Visit the EAG website for more information about how the EAG is working to improve your experience at the lab!

item.title: Fermilab Fridays with the Chicago Steel
item.creator: jkoester
item.description: Special offer for Fermilab employees and families to see the Chicago Steel Hockey Team. Fast paced Family Fun is now just minutes away at the Fox Valley Ice Arena in Geneva. Fermilab employees are invited to experience Chicagoland’s only Tier 1 Junior Team on Fermilab Fridays (1/29, 2/26, 3/25, 4/8) with the Chicago Steel! Puck drops at 7:30pm. Defense Preferred Tickets are just $12.00 ($16.75 value). To purchase these discounted tickets visit www.steelgroups.com and enter password Fermilab. There is a... More »
item.comment: Special offer for Fermilab employees and families to see the Chicago Steel Hockey Team. Fast paced Family Fun is now just minutes away at the Fox Valley Ice Arena in Geneva. Fermilab employees are invited to experience Chicagoland’s only Tier 1 Junior Team on Fermilab Fridays (1/29, 2/26, 3/25, 4/8) with the Chicago Steel! Puck drops at 7:30pm. Defense Preferred Tickets are just $12.00 ($16.75 value). To purchase these discounted tickets visit www.steelgroups.com and enter password Fermilab. There is a $1.50 per ticket processing fee applied to all online orders. Tickets purchased on the day of the game are an additional $2 per ticket. To order tickets by phone or for more info contact Dave Campione 855-51-STEEL. dcampione@chicagosteelhockeyteam.com

item.title: Winter driving awareness
item.creator: asands
item.description: Remember that winter driving requires patience, and give yourself extra time to get to your destination in inclement weather.
item.comment:
Most drivers in Illinois are familiar with the dangerous driving conditions that can occur, especially in winter. Unfortunately many drivers fail to slow down in hazardous conditions, even though they are aware of the dangers.  Remember that winter driving requires patience, and give yourself extra time to get to your destination in inclement weather.

Check out the video below, produced by the Montana Department of Justice, that shows the dangers of driving too fast for conditions.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hvhRHiskRIc

You can find additional winter driving tips in this Fermilab Today article:  http://www.fnal.gov/pub/today/archive/archive_2008/today08-02-11.html
